stream_context.summary: Kaze designed and built the game's final level, a 'retro section' that combines elements from all 15 Mario 64 courses into a single vertical map. He focused on level layout, asset implementation, and managing technical constraints like memory, while also discussing his development philosophy and plans for a potential Nintendo takedown.

development_findings.summary: The final level is a 'retro section' that combines elements from all 15 Mario 64 stages into a single, large, vertical map, inspired by the 'Only Up 64' hack.
development_findings.quote: It's like all the Mario 64 stages in one basically.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is actively fixing the original game's distorted UV mapping on models to improve visual quality.
development_findings.quote: I cannot tolerate what the original developers did here unfortunately.

development_findings.summary: Memory management is a significant technical constraint, with Kaze frequently checking RAM usage and implementing code to handle potential buffer overflows.
development_findings.quote: Our main issue here is that we are running out of memory.

development_findings.summary: A core design principle for the game is to allow for creative skips but to avoid exploits that completely trivialize sections of the level.
development_findings.quote: I want player to at least be creative when they skip something, otherwise it's not fun.

development_findings.summary: Kaze intends for the game to be fully completable without using the new, extended moveset, ensuring the core challenge is accessible.
development_findings.quote: I kind of want this game to be beatable without Mario's extended moveset.

development_findings.summary: The overworld is planned to be a representation of the entire Yoshi's Island, which will be split into multiple sections due to its large scale.
Kaze discovered that the original Mario 64 uses vertex colors for lighting effects in more places than commonly thought, a detail he is replicating.
development_findings.quote: I'm actually working on a video called Every Shade on Mario 64 So I have seen all of them.

context_findings.summary: Kaze has a defiant, 'win-win' philosophy regarding a potential Nintendo takedown, planning to pivot to a commercial indie game by replacing assets if necessary.
context_findings.quote: If Nintendo takes it down, perfect. I can re-run it, I can sell it on Steam, I'm going to be rich. If they don't take it down, also great. I get to make my mod. It's a win-win.

context_findings.summary: Kaze acknowledges he is on Nintendo's radar, stating they have previously taken down over 70 of his videos, though not for several years.
context_findings.quote: You do realise Nintendo took down over 70 of my videos, like I'm very clearly on Nintendo's radar.

context_findings.summary: In response to community feedback on a different project, Kaze showed a willingness to censor potentially offensive content, deciding to re-theme a level to avoid causing offense.
context_findings.quote: I'm thinking everything is going to be replaced with just like bowser flags and like all koopas are bastards stickers and stuff like that i think that's the solution here because if we all perceive it to be offensive then that's bad obviously.

context_findings.summary: Kaze's personal life is currently busy, with his parents visiting for 10 days and his daughter's baptism, which will impact his ability to stream.
Kaze believes Sonic games have better music than Mario on average but suffer from a core gameplay loop that punishes the player for going fast, a problem he feels is difficult to fix.
context_findings.quote: I think the games just need a lot of experimentation before they ever showed up being good.

biobak.summary: Biobak created most of the levels for a separate, paid commission hack Kaze demonstrated, which involves buying and selling drugs.
Kaze jokingly refers to having created Biobak, indicating a close and informal working relationship.
biobak.quote: I made Biobak I created them with my own two hands

zeina.summary: Kaze mentions he and his wife, Zeina, are currently 'hate watching' the anime 'Seven Deadly Sins' together, offering a small insight into their shared personal life.

key_stories.title: Nintendo Takedown Contingency Plan
key_stories.summary: Kaze outlined his contingency plan for a potential Nintendo takedown. Rather than fearing it, he views it as an opportunity to pivot the project into a commercial indie game by replacing all Nintendo assets, creating a 'win-win' scenario for himself.
key_stories.challenge: The constant legal threat from Nintendo looms over the project, potentially leading to a cease and desist.
key_stories.process: Kaze analyzed the potential consequences of a takedown and formulated a contingency plan. This involves stripping Nintendo's code and assets and replacing them with original work, such as changing 'Return to Yoshi's Island' to 'Return to Dinosaur Island'.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze developed a 'win-win' philosophy where a takedown is not a failure, but a trigger to pivot the project into a commercial indie game by replacing all Nintendo IP, which he believes he can do legally.
key_stories.key_quote: If Nintendo takes it down, perfect. I can re-run it, I can sell it on Steam, I'm going to be rich. If they don't take it down, also great. I get to make my mod. It's a win-win.

key_stories.title: Live Collaborative Level Design
key_stories.summary: While live-streaming the creation of the final level, Kaze received feedback from a viewer that his initial layout was too simple. He agreed and immediately began redesigning the level in real-time to be more fragmented and difficult, demonstrating a collaborative and iterative design process.
key_stories.challenge: Designing the massive, final 'retro section' level in a way that is engaging and appropriately difficult.
key_stories.process: Kaze started with a basic layout of combined level chunks. A viewer suggested it should be more split up. Kaze agreed this was a 'valuable idea' and immediately began altering the geometry to break up platforms and increase the difficulty.
key_stories.outcome: The level's design shifted to be more fragmented and challenging, creating a more varied and interesting platforming experience based directly on the live feedback.
key_stories.key_quote: I see we can split this a lot more i mean i think that's a valuable idea splitting this a lot more also lets us add a little bit more difficulty to this.

key_stories.title: Censoring an Offensive Level
key_stories.summary: After learning that a level in a side project was perceived as offensive, Kaze immediately decided to alter it. He planned to change the controversial imagery to fit an in-universe 'anti-Bowser protest' theme, showing his responsiveness to community concerns.
key_stories.challenge: A level in a separate, commissioned hack received community feedback that its use of rainbow flags in a violent context was offensive to the LGBT community.
key_stories.process: Kaze acknowledged the community's perception as valid, regardless of his original intent. He brainstormed a solution to replace the flags with Bowser flags and add stickers like 'All Koopas Are Bastards' to change the context entirely.
key_stories.outcome: A plan was created to re-theme the level into an 'anti-Bowser protest,' removing the potentially offensive imagery and ensuring the content is not hurtful.
key_stories.key_quote: I think that's the solution here because if we all perceive it to be offensive then that's bad obviously.
